ranked_diseases.explanation: This syndrome is the classic and most common cause of the described triad: hypoparathyroidism (due to parathyroid gland hypoplasia/aplasia), aplasia/hypoplasia of the thymus, and subsequent T lymphocytopenia. These features result from abnormal development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, which are affected by the 22q11.2 deletion.

While less commonly presenting solely with this specific triad, CHARGE syndrome (caused by mutations in CHD7) can involve hypoparathyroidism and immune deficiencies, including T-cell issues, due to thymic hypoplasia. It is a broad developmental disorder with some potential phenotypic overlap, making it a distant but relevant differential.
